available.name: available
available.comment:
Returns true if the API is available. The common causes of an API not being avilable are:

  • a permission is missing in the application's manifest.json file
  • the API is defined on a newer version of Chrome then the current runtime

clear.name: clear
clear.comment: Clears the specified notification. chrome/chrome_ext.ChromeNotifications.clear.notificationId: The id of the notification to be cleared. This is returned by notifications.create method. callback: Called to indicate whether a matching notification existed.

create.name: create
create.comment: Creates and displays a notification. chrome/chrome_ext.ChromeNotifications.create.notificationId: Identifier of the notification. If it is empty, this method generates an id. If it matches an existing notification, this method first clears that notification before proceeding with the create operation. chrome/chrome_ext.ChromeNotifications.create.options: Contents of the notification. callback: Returns the notification id (either supplied or generated) that represents the created notification.

getAll.name: getAll
getAll.comment: Retrieves all the notifications. callback: Returns the set of notification_ids currently in the system.

getPermissionLevel.name: getPermissionLevel
getPermissionLevel.comment: Retrieves whether the user has enabled notifications from this app or extension. callback: Returns the current permission level.

update.name: update
update.comment: Updates an existing notification. chrome/chrome_ext.ChromeNotifications.update.notificationId: The id of the notification to be updated. This is returned by notifications.create method. chrome/chrome_ext.ChromeNotifications.update.options: Contents of the notification to update to. callback: Called to indicate whether a matching notification existed.

available.name: available
available.comment:
Returns true if the API is available. The common causes of an API not being avilable are:

  • a permission is missing in the application's manifest.json file
  • the API is defined on a newer version of Chrome then the current runtime

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides chrome/chrome_ext.ChromeNotifications.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and chrome/chrome_ext.ChromeNotifications.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the chrome/chrome_ext.ChromeNotifications.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
chrome/chrome_ext.ChromeNotifications.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to chrome/chrome_ext.ChromeNotifications.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If chrome/chrome_ext.ChromeNotifications.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of chrome/chrome_ext.ChromeNotifications.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.
